In attempt to reduce the use of toxic AlCl3 and develop more environmentally benign procedure for the oligomerization of 1-decene, three ionic liquids with different structures were supported on halloysite nano clay. The obtained supported ionic liquids, denoted as Hal-[MIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl−, were then utilized along with AlCl3 with mass ratio of 1:1 as oligomerization catalysts. The used AlCl3 content in these systems was half of the catalyst amount in the classic AlCl3-catalyzed α-olefin oligomerizations. The features of the resultant polyalphaolefins were characterized via viscometry, 1HNMR, 13CNMR, GC-Mass, and SimDis analyses and compared with those of polyalphaolefin derived from neat AlCl3. It was found that by using supported ionic liquids with almost half amount of AlCl3, PAOs with practically similar features to the one derived from AlCl3 can be obtained. Moreover, it was demonstrated that the nature of ionic liquid was also influential on the properties of the resulting PAO and in the case of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−, PAO with the lowest molecular weight, kinematic viscosity and polydispersity index and the highest viscosity index was obtained. Graphical abstracts Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ionic liquid Heterogeneous catalyst Oligomerization Polyalphaolefins Introduction Ionic liquids (ILs) are well-known organic salts [1-5] that have found growing applications in last decade [6-8]. In fact, development of new synthetic routes, such as ultrasonic and microwave-assisted procedures as well as the possibility of use of numerous organic cations and inorganic/organic anions allow design and fabrication of ILs with specific features [6, 9-11]. On the other hand, the possibility of synthesis of ILs from bio-based materials as well as introduction of chiral centers on ILs opened new arena for the applications of these compounds [7]. One of the mostly studied utilities of ILs is for Green chemistry. In this context, ILs can be used both as environmentally benign solvents and catalysts [12-14]. On the other hand, ILs can be easily stabilized on supporting materials to furnish heterogeneous catalysts with high recyclability. One of the supporting materials that has been focused in recent years is halloysite (Hal) nanoclay [15, 16]. The main features of this natural clay that make it center of growing attention are its biocompatibility and unique physicochemical properties [17-24]. More precisely, this aluminosilicate clay exhibits tubular morphology with a hollow space inside. Moreover, the electric charges of inner and outer surfaces of Hal tubes are different [25-27]. These features allow both Hal surfaces to be functionalized and tuned for specific applications [28-30]. In the last decade, various examples of Hal with utility for the catalysis [31, 32] and other domains [33, 34] have been reported. Polyalphaolefins (PAOs) are referred to oligomers with linear α-olefins, mainly C6 to C12. These compounds found extensive applications in engine lubricants [35-37]. The distinguishing features of PAOs compared to mineral oils are their higher viscosity indices (VI), superior thermal oxidative stability as well as lower pour point [36]. PAO synthesis is a three-step catalytic procedure, consists of oligomerization, hydrogenation and distillation. To date, various catalysts, such as Lewis acids [38-40] and coordination catalysts [41-44] have been developed for oligomerization of α-olefins. Although, many successes have been achieved in coordination oligomerization of high α-olefins to obtain uniformly structured PAOs with special characteristic [44-46], the industry still uses BF3 and AlCl3 in the synthesis of conventional grade PAOs [47]. These catalysts can result in PAOs with different viscosities. Notably, the main drawback of these catalysts is their high toxicity. In recent years, emerging catalysts, including liquid coordination complexes [48] and ILs [49] have been propounded. Considering the environmental concerns and the fact that the features of the synthesized PAO is significantly affected by the used catalyst [50], development of efficient and environmentally benign catalytic system has been focused [38, 48, 51]. In the following of our research on the use of natural clays for the catalysis [31, 52] and use of supported ILs [53] as heterogeneous catalysts and in attempt to develop a less-toxic procedure for oligomerization of α-olefins, herein we wish to report the utility of Hal-supported ILs-AlCl3 catalytic systems with half content of AlCl3 compared to classic AlCl3-catalyzed procedure for the synthesis of PAOs. The effects of these catalysts on the features of the as-prepared PAOs are investigated and compared with those of neat AlCl3. Experimental Reagents To prepare the catalysts and examine their catalytic performances for the oligomerization, the following reagents and chemicals have been utilized: Hal (purchased from Sigma-Aldrich), 1-decene, (3-chloropropyl) trimethoxysilane (CPTES), imidazole, 1-methylimidazole, 1-butyl chloride, and benzyl chloride, AlCl3, all was purchased from Merck Co. Germany and applied as received. Instruments To obtain molecular weights and distributions of the prepared lubricants, GPC instrument (GPC Agilent 1100) was applied. This analysis was conducted by using chloroform as solvent and the flow rate of 1.000 mL/min. To record high-resolution 1H-NMR and 13CNMR spectra of the synthesized PAOs at ambient temperature, Bruker DRX 400 MHz NMR spectrometer was employed. The used solvent for NMR spectroscopy was CDCl3. In the case of 1H-NMR spectroscopy, the chemical shift of CDCl3 solvent (δ = 7.26 ppm) was determined as an internal standard. 13CNMR spectroscopy was run under fully H decoupled condition with the following details: delay time: 6s, number of scans: 6000, pulse angle: 90 °, PulProg: zgig, D1: 10.0 s. To shed light on the carbon number and boiling points of the prepared lubricants, HT-CNS SimDis (Agilent 7890 A gas chromatograph equipped with FID, NCD, and SCD and AC Simulated Distillation Software) was applied along with a detailed hydrocarbon analyzer (DHA, Agilent 7890 A Gas Chromatograph with FID and AC DHA Software). Kinematic viscosities at two temperatures (40 and 100°C, denoted as KV40 and KV100, respectively) as well as Viscosity Index (VI) values were estimated based on ASTM D445 and ASTM D2270, respectively. Synthesis of supported ILs Synthesis of Hal-Cl In this study, three Hal-supported IL catalysts, Hal-[MIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl−, have been synthesized. To synthesize all systems, Hal was first Cl-functionalized. To this purpose, Hal (1 g) was suspended in dry toluene (50 mL) and sonicated for 10 min (150 W at ambient temperature). Subsequently, CPTES (2.5 mL) was added and the mixture was refluxed at 110°C under N2 atmosphere for 20 h. At the end of the reaction, the precipitate (Hal-Cl) was filtered off, washed repeatedly with toluene and dried at 60°C for 24 h. Synthesis of Hal-[MIM]+ Cl− To prepare Hal-[MIM]+ Cl−, Hal-Cl (1 g) was well-dispersed in n-heptane (30 mL) and then 1-methylimidazole (0.5 g) was added and the mixture was stirred at 90°C for 24 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the solid was filtered, washed with n-heptane several times and then dried at 80°C overnight, Fig. 1 . Using TGA analysis, the loading of CPTES on Hal was estimated to be ~ 3 wt.%. Synthesis of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− and Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl− To synthesize both Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− and Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl−, Hal-Cl was first treated with imidazole. In more detail, imidazole (0.5 g) was added to the suspension of Hal-Cl (1g) in n-heptane (30 mL). Afterwards, the mixture was stirred at 90°C for 24 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the solid (Hal-Im) was filtered off, washed with n-heptane and dried at 80°C overnight. TGA confirmed that loading of Im was about 8.5 wt.%. In the second step, Hal-Im (1 g) was reacted with 1-butyl chloride, and benzyl chloride to furnish Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− and Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl− respectively. To this purpose, to the suspension of Hal-Im in n-hexane (1 g in 30 mL), 1-butyl chloride (1.1 g) or benzyl chloride (1.1 g) was added and the mixture was refluxed for 24 h. At the end, the precipitate was separated, washed with n-heptane several times and dried at 80°C overnight. Oligomerization of 1-decene PAO synthesis was realized by oligomerization of 1-decene. The oligomerization procedure was similar to our previously reported method [54]. Briefly, to a reactor that has been purged with N2 gas, catalyst containing a mixture of AlCl3 and IL with AlCl3/IL weight ratio of 1 and dry hexane (5 mL) were charged. Then, the temperature of the reactor was adjusted to 80°C. After mixing for 15 min, 1-decene (30 g) was added to the reactor and the temperature was elevated to 100°C. The reaction was continued for 1 h and at the end of the oligomerization, the reactor was discharged and the resultant PAO was collected. Result and discussion The comparison of the features of the PAOs derived from different catalytic systems In attempt to find more environmentally friendly catalyst for the synthesis of PAOs and reduce the required content of AlCl3, the catalytic performance of IL-based catalysts along with AlCl3 with half loading of the classic AlCl3- based procedure has been targeted. Furthermore, as bare ILs are mostly homogeneous catalysts with tedious recovery, it was determined to support them on Hal clay. As the nature of IL can affect the properties of the resultant PAOs, it was decided to study the effects of three different Hal-supported ILs, Hal-[MIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl−, on the characteristics of the as-prepared PAOs and compare them with bare AlCl3. To this purpose, oligomerization of 1-decene was carried out under similar condition (see the Experimental section) using four catalysts and VI, molecular weight (Mn), polydispersity index (PDI), KV40 and KV100 of the prepared PAOs were compared, Table 1 . As shown in Table 1, the GPC analysis of the obtained PAOs (Fig. 2 ) indicated that use of Hal-supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts resulted in PAOs with Mn values slightly lower than that of AlCl3. Among three Hal-supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts, Hal-[BuIM]+Cl−/AlCl3 led to the lowest Mn value, while Hal-[MIM]+ Cl−/AlCl3 furnished PAOs with Mn value very close to that of AlCl3. Comparison of PDI value of the four synthesized PAOs, Table 1, inferred that the PAOs from Hal-supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts have narrower PDI values. In more detail, the order of decrease of PDI in the four samples is as follow: AlCl3> Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl−/AlCl3> Hal-[MIM]+ Cl−/AlCl3> Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−/AlCl3. The next measured parameter was VI. This is an important feature of the lubricant that implied the change of the viscosity as a function of temperature. For industrial applications, the lubricants with high VI are more demanding and have broader applications. The measured VI values of the four synthesized PAOs confirmed that Hal-supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts could furnish PAOs with higher VI values compared to AlCl3. This issue established the superiority of this class of the catalysts compared to the conventional AlCl3. Comparison of KV40 and KV100 of the prepared PAOs affirmed that Hal-supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts resulted in PAOs with KV40 and KV100 slightly lower than that of AlCl3. To summarize this section, comparison of the features of PAOs derived from Hal-supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts with the one obtained from AlCl3 catalyst established that former catalysts, in which the content of the used AlCl3 was reduced to half, led to the features similar (Mn and KV) or superior (VI) to that of AlCl3 catalyst. Investigation of unsaturation in the as-prepared PAOs Another important parameter in PAOs is the nature of their unsaturated bonds. To elucidate the entity of C=C unsaturated bonds in the as-prepared PAOs, 1HNMR spectroscopy was exploited; Fig. 3 . The chemical shift (δ) values for various types of hydrogens are listed in Table 2 . The vinylic hydrogen can be divided into three types, vinylene (2Vn), or tri-substituted vinylene (3Vn) and vinylidene (Vd), Fig. 4 . Analysis of the vinylic hydrogen in the as-prepared PAOs, Table 3 , indicated that there was no mono-substituted C=C bond. Furthermore, 3Vn vinyl type that was furnished through ending of the chains by 1,2-insertion of the monomer was dominant in all PAOs and the less formed vinyl type was Vd. All of 3Vn, 2Vn and Vd can turn into branched structures upon PAO hydrogenation that is favorable for lubricant ability. Hence, the as-prepared PAOs have suitable lubricating ability. Branching type and content of the as-prepared PAOs The kind of CH3 branching, a factor that can affect the VI of the as-prepared PAOs, was also investigated via 13CNMR spectroscopy along with DEPT-135 analysis, Fig. 5 . The observed peaks in 13CNMR spectra are the peaks at δ=14.0 ppm (CH3 end group), 22.8 ppm (α-CH2), 29.0-30.6 ppm (β-CH2), and 32.1 ppm (δ-CH2) [55, 56]. Moreover, multiple peaks at δ=26.8 and 34.3 ppm are attributed to the first side chain C near to the main chain, while peaks at δ=28.0 and 32.7 ppm can be assigned to the methane grafted to the short chain and long chain, respectively [56]. Distortionless Enhancement by Polarization Transfer (DEPT) was exploited to study the type of carbons in the as-prepared PAOs. In DEPT, the peaks under the baseline can be assigned to the CH2, while the peaks above the baseline can be ascribed to the other carbons. In Fig. 6 , the DEPT-135 spectra of the two synthesized oligomers are illustrated. Considering the intensity of each peak to the total peaks surface area, the content of each type of methyl group was estimated, Table 4 . According to the literature [55], the best lubricant ability can be achieved in oligomers with higher content of long alkyl chain, lower ethyl branching and lower methyl branches in the center. Comparison of the share of CH3 types of Hal-supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts with those of AlCl3 showed that former catalysts resulted in higher content of long chain branching (the sum of entries 3 and 5). This issue was also confirmed by higher VI of this class of catalysts compared to AlCl3. Using 13CNMR spectra and Equations 1 and 2, branching ratio and short-chain branching values for all of the as-prepared PAOs have been measured [57]. (1) b r a n c h i n g r a t i o = [ 15 × ∑ ( 13 C int e g r a l 11 − 17 p p m ) ] / [ 15 × ∑ ( 13 C int e g r a l 11 − 17 p p m ) + 14 × ∑ ( 13 C int e g r a l 18 − 44 p p m ) ] (2) s h o r t − c h a i n b r a n c h i n g p e r c e n t a g e = [ ∑ ( C int e g r a l s h o r t − c h a i n m e t h y l ) / ∑ ( C int e g r a l a l l m e t h y l ) ] × 100 The results, summarized in Table 5 , indicated that among the examined catalysts, Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl−/AlCl3 resulted in the PAO with the lowest branching ratio, while Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−/AlCl3 yielded PAO with the lowest percent of short-chain branching. These results confirmed that Hal-supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts led to the formation of PAOs with more uniform structures and consequently, higher VI. PAO fractionation by boiling point The as-prepared PAOs were also analyzed with GC-Mass and the observed peaks were identified according to the literature [58]. In Table 6 , the percentages of the oligomer type (dimer, trimer, tetramer and >tetramer for each PAO are listed. As tabulated, Hal-[MIM]+Cl−/AlCl3 led to the formation of the highest trimer and tetramer that their carbon atoms are equivalent with the composition of mostly used commercial PAO grades. The as-prepared PAOs were also characterized with high-performance capillary gas chromatograph combined with simulation distillation software (SimDis). The resultant SimDis curves of all PAOs are depicted in Fig. 7 . The obtained data indicated that the as-prepared PAOs exhibited almost a broad peak that can contain several tiny sharp peaks. Characterization of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− Confirming the superior capability of supported IL containing catalysts in high VI polyalphaolefin production, Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−IL was selected as a representative supported catalyst, and its structure was analyzed via various characterization techniques, such as XRD, SEM, TGA and elemental mapping analysis. XRD To investigate the structure of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−, XRD analysis was conducted. Moreover, to elucidate whether [BuIM]+ Cl− IL located on the Hal surface or within its lumen, XRD pattern of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− was compared with that of Hal. As depicted in Fig. 8 , XRD pattern of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− showed all of the diffraction peaks of Hal (2θ = 18.8°, 20.6°, 25.2°, 36.7°, 39.0°, 56.3° and 62.5° (JCPDS No. 29-1487) [59-61]). This approves that introduction of [BuIM]+ Cl− did not affect the instinct cylindrical structure of Hal. Another conclusion that can be derived from the comparison of the two XRD patterns is that [BuIM]+ Cl− is located on the exterior surface of Hal. According to the literature [62], in the case of insertion of ILs in the interior space of Hal, the diffraction peaks will shift. Hence, the absence of any displacement of the diffraction peaks of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− confirmed that IL was on the outer surface of Hal. SEM SEM image of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− is illustrated in Fig. 9 . Similar to pristine Hal, Fig. S1, Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− also exhibited tubular morphology. In some parts, the tubes packed together to form aggregates. SEM analysis indicated that even after introduction of [BuIM]+ Cl−, Hal preserved its tubular morphology. Elemental mapping analysis The result of elemental mapping analysis of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− is presented in Fig. 10 . Among the detected elements, Cl, C and N atoms can be indicative of [BuIM]+ Cl− IL. High dispersion of these elements approves that IL was well-dispersed on Hal support. TGA Another analysis that can confirm conjugation of the functional group in each step of synthesis of the catalyst is TGA. In Fig. 11 , the TG curves of Hal, Hal-Cl, Hal-Im and Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− are illustrated. TG curve of Hal contained two weight losses, including loss of water (150 °C) and dehydroxylation of Hal loss (at 480 °C) [63, 64]. Thermal stability of Hal-Cl sample is slightly lower than that of Hal and an additional weight loss step at 320 °C can be observed in this sample that is due to the degradation of CPTES. Using this analysis the content of was estimated to be ~ 3 wt.%. Regarding Hal-Im, the content of Im was calculated as ~ 8.5 wt.%. Finally, comparison of the TG curves of Hal and Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−, showed that the loading of [BuIM]+ Cl− was ~10 wt.%. FTIR spectrum of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− is illustrated in Fig. 12 . In this spectrum, the absorbance bands at 1053 cm−1 and 536 cm−1 are due to the Si-O stretching and Al-O-Si vibration of Hal structure respectively. Moreover, the bands at 3695 cm−1 and 3622 cm−1 are indicative of inner -OH functionalities of Hal. The characteristic band of IL appeared at 1635 cm−1 that is attributed to the –C=N functionality of imidazolium ring. Conclusion With the aim of decrement of the loading of AlCl3 that is a toxic chemical, three Hal supported ILs, Hal-[MIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl−, were prepared and then applied in combination with AlCl3 for promoting oligomerization of 1-decene. The loading of AlCl3 in these catalytic systems was half of the conventional AlCl3 - catalyzed oligomerization. To elucidate the effects of the supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts on the properties of the resultant PAOs, the features of the obtained PAOs were fully characterized via viscometry, 1HNMR, 13CNMR, GC-Mass, and SimDis analyses and compared with the one derived from neat AlCl3. Gratifyingly, it was found that by reduction of AlCl3 into half, in Hal supported IL/AlCl3 catalysts, the PAOs with properties almost similar to AlCl3, but with higher VI value, thanks to IL presence, were achieved. The origin of this performance was detected in higher long chain branching content of PAOs from IL containing supported catalysts. To unravel the structure of supported catalysts, and confirm grafting of IL moiety on Hal support, Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl− (as a representative catalyst) was further analyzed by different instruments including SEM, TGA, and XRD. It was found that while Hal functionalization by [BuIM]+ Cl− moiety was successfully performed, its tubular morphology was still preserved intact. In brief, the obtained results confirmed that the suggested IL supported Hal catalysts can be regarded as good alternatives for the commercialized AlCl3 route in large scale PAO production. coredata.dc:description: In attempt to reduce the use of toxic AlCl3 and develop more environmentally benign procedure for the oligomerization of 1-decene, three ionic liquids with different structures were supported on halloysite nano clay. The obtained supported ionic liquids, denoted as Hal-[MIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−, Hal-[BeIM]+ Cl−, were then utilized along with AlCl3 with mass ratio of 1:1 as oligomerization catalysts. The used AlCl3 content in these systems was half of the catalyst amount in the classic AlCl3-catalyzed α-olefin oligomerizations. The features of the resultant polyalphaolefins were characterized via viscometry, 1HNMR, 13CNMR, GC-Mass, and SimDis analyses and compared with those of polyalphaolefin derived from neat AlCl3. It was found that by using supported ionic liquids with almost half amount of AlCl3, PAOs with practically similar features to the one derived from AlCl3 can be obtained. Moreover, it was demonstrated that the nature of ionic liquid was also influential on the properties of the resulting PAO and in the case of Hal-[BuIM]+ Cl−, PAO with the lowest molecular weight, kinematic viscosity and polydispersity index and the highest viscosity index was obtained.
coredata.dc:title: New less-toxic halloysite-supported ionic liquid/AlCl3 oligomerization catalysts: a comparative study on the effects of various ionic liquids on the properties of polyalphaolefins
